en: Interview with Dianne Britton, volunteer with the Red Cross. Britton discusses her role with the Red Cross in connecting survivors with mental health resources. She also recounts some of the general feelings and mood found in the shelters, and compares this disaster to others that she has experienced. This is a representative quote from the interview: "You can't make this kind of thing better. There's nothing you can do to fix it or make it better. To me, the only thing you can do, is not make it worse."

Interview with Dianne Britton, volunteer with the Red Cross. Britton discusses her role with the Red Cross in connecting survivors with mental health resources. She also recounts some of the general feelings and mood found in the shelters, and compares this disaster to others that she has experienced. This is a representative quote from the interview: "You can't make this kind of thing better. There's nothing you can do to fix it or make it better. To me, the only thing you can do, is not make it worse."

Tell me your name, your position, and about your connection to the region.
Tell me about what led you to be involved in mental health.
How long have you been a volunteer with the Red Cross?
Tell me about what was going on with you leading into the fire?
So you went in before they called you? Did you go in at Knoxville or Gatlinburg?
What day did you come into Knoxville, the day of the fire, or during the days leading up to it?
What was the first thing you saw when you got there? Tell us about what you did after intitially arriving.
Did you talk to any people on that visit or was it just observation?
What did some of the people share with you that day?
How much awareness did they, or you, have of what was going on?
Tell us what a command center is like.
Was your job to assess the situation and connect jpeople with mental health services?
Did that help you get your job done since the Dolly Foundation was providing resources?
After you assessed the shelters, what was the next step for you? Did you go out into the community at all?
Did you feel like you had enough help on the mental health side?
Did it feel like the people in these facilities were reaching out to you? What was their reaction?
Are there stories, excluding specific clients, that stood out to you?
How long were you up there?
How does this compare to other events you've been part of?
Did you also work with the firefighters and first responders?
Have you been back to Gatlinburg since you left?
What did your heart take away from this?
What did your heart take away from this?
Is there anything else you wanted to share that I haven't asked?
Kodak discussed in Interview with Dianne Britton, 2020-01-10
